info.game_comments: Game data retrieved from an alternate archive.

(2, 1).clue: It's the term for 3 strikes in a row (gobble gobble)

(3, 1).clue: Illinois & Texas both claim to be the home of this battered & deep-fried wiener on a stick

(4, 1).clue: Now voiced by Wayne Allwine, this character was originally voiced by Walt Disney himself

(5, 1).clue: In the 1600s, the pirate Koxinga took this island also known as Formosa from the Dutch

(6, 1).clue: This type of plane carries packages, not passengers

(2, 2).clue: Appropriately, in a Woolworth split, these 2 pins are left standing

(3, 2).clue: Dried, smoked or even roasted, this fish is "king" in Alaska

(4, 2).clue: This Norfolk, Virginia-born Las Vegas superstar claims to be a descendant of Pocahontas

(5, 2).clue: The main job of a pirate, "to take things by force", it's from a German word

(6, 2).clue: The FDA requires that this butter substitute be fortified with Vitamin A

(2, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew presents from the National Bowling Stadium in Reno, NV.) In 1997, Jeremy Sonnenfeld achieved the American Bowling Congress's first perfect series: 3 games totalling this number

(3, 3).clue: Nopales, used in salads in the southwest, are the cooked-until-tender leaves of these, with the spines removed

(4, 3).clue: Good golly, his real name is Richard Wayne Penniman

(5, 3).clue: A favorite weapon of pirates; being stabbed by one 20 times helped kill the pirate Blackbeard

(6, 3).clue: It's a signal by bugle for the soldiers to attack

(2, 4).clue: A trademark of Brunswick, you might say this type of bowling, with laser lights, fog & music is out of this world!

(3, 4).clue: Marionberries aren't from D.C.; they're from Oregon & are a variety of these berries

(4, 4).clue: Sen. Wayne Morse, who spoke nonstop for 22 hours & 26 minutes in 1953, set a then-record for one of these

(5, 4).clue: Some of his famous treasure has been found on Gardiners Island off Long Island

(6, 4).clue: This city was named for one of the founders of American Express

(2, 5).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew presents from the National Bowling Stadium in Reno, NV.) When a righty bowler's ball hits the left side of the head pin to make a strike, it's called this, even outside New York

(3, 5).clue: The steamed blue ones from Chesapeake Bay are served by the dozen in Baltimore restaurants

(4, 5).clue: Before the 1804 Lewis & Clark expedition, William Clark served as an Army officer under this "crazy" General

(5, 5).clue: A New York bridge that gets you to Staten Island is named for this privateer turned explorer

(6, 5).clue: It's the lingo peculiar to a particular trade or group

(1, 1).clue: Mesocarp & mesoderm refer to layers in this position

(4, 1).clue: In size, it's the smallest independent country in the world

(5, 1).clue: Goat cheese is a food; this was the Chiricahua Apache leader who took on the Army in the 1860s

(6, 1).clue: Superman's classic nickname that's the material used in S.O.S. Pads for scouring & polishing

(1, 2).clue: An astrocyte is a cell shaped like this

(2, 2).clue: The Indian tribe that Dances With Wolves befriends

(3, 2).clue: In 1924 A T & T introduced a printing telegraph system under this name that became widely used

(4, 2).clue: All 181 square miles of it are found in the eastern Pyrenees mountains

(5, 2).clue: Ephedrine is an asthma drug; this is the actress who starred in "The Birds"

(6, 2).clue: "A.I" co-star who's a TV drama about crime & justice from the perspective of the police & the prosecuting D.A.s

(1, 3).clue: (Hi, I'm Dave Mustaine of the rock group Megadeth.) As in the Nuclear war term "megadeaths", the Greek prefix mega - translates as this

(2, 3).clue: He played Cantor Rabinovitch in "The Jazz Singer" in 1980 & Hamlet in 1948

(4, 3).clue: Discovered by Columbus in 1498, invaded by the U.S. in 1983
